item.title: Leopold Aschenbrenner responds to me on AI risk
item.description:
Leopold Aschenbrenner on Twitter

“New post: response to @tylercowen on AI risk During covid, neither 1) “lockdown forever, ” nor 2) “let ’er rip” was tenable. The same goes for AI. There is a better way: 3) a) Operation Warp Speed for alignment + b) AI lab standards/monitoring.”

URL: https://twitter.com/leopoldasch/status/1643981423186165768

source: Thursday assorted links

item.title: Why isn’t Europe doing worse?
item.description:
Frederik Ducrozet on Twitter

“🇪🇺 Over the past 9 months, Europe has gone through a massive terms of trade shock worth 6% of GDP, followed by the fastest monetary tightening cycle in history. Today the services sector is booming and the labour market is super hot. It’s crazy when you think about it.”

URL: https://twitter.com/fwred/status/1643522347935170560

item.title: Did the Counter-Reformation harm science?
item.description:
Whyvert on Twitter

“New paper: before the Counter-Reformation, Catholic and Protestant cities had comparable numbers of scientists per capita. Afterwards, Catholic cities experienced a persistent relative decline. Counter-Reformation’s search for heresy was a negative shock to science.”

URL: https://twitter.com/whyvert/status/1643416014250467328

item.title: Given the Restrict Act, Don't Ban TikTok
item.description:
While others have already written similar posts, given my previous position it seems necessary for me to do so as well - the Restrict Act is a no good very bad bill, and having seen the bill I realize that I was wrong to support banning TikTok. For a while I have been in favor of banning TikTok, if it does not divest its Chinese ownership and modify the …

URL: https://thezvi.substack.com/p/given-the-restrict-act-dont-ban-tiktok?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Links to Consider, 4/7

item.title: Relevance Realization, Cerebral Hemispheres, and the Reconciliation of Science and Mythology
item.description:
Iain McGilchrist’s 2009 book The Master and His Emissary is destined to be a classic. Even if he’s wrong about any particular idea in the book, the scope of his thesis and the amount of evidence he brings to bear on it makes it interesting and useful. McGilchrist claims that cultures can come to take on the characteristics of the left or right cerebral …

URL: https://brettandersen.substack.com/p/relevance-realization-cerebral-hemispheres?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Links to Consider, 4/7
